para.text: Traditionally they have been two approaches to the security issue when running applets within a web browser.

li.text: One approach is to use a virtual machine (VM) that is capable of restricting the activities that the applet can perform on the client machine. For example, such an applet would not be allowed to write local files or access any computer other than the one from which it originated. This is called the "sand box" approach (since the applet is kept within a safe environment where it can do no damage). The problem with this approach is that these restrictions can often prevent an applet from being able to do any "real work" and that it is very difficult to implement a truly safe virtual machine.

An alternative approach is to use "code signing". In this case each applet comes complete with a digital signature that identifies the original publisher and virtually guarantees that the code cannot be modified in transit. The idea is that most users, given that they know the source of an applet, will be able to make a reasonable decision as to whether the code should be trusted to run on their computer or not without causing damage. An advantage of this scheme is that a trusted applet has access to all the facilities of the local computer and can therefore host some quite serious functionality. The obvious disadvantage is that misplacing trust in a particular supplier can have dire consequences. This is the approach that Microsoft take to guarantee the security of downloadable ActiveX components.
